Edward Arlington Robinson Bora 1869
Died 1935
Edward Arlington Robinson ms typical of the austere lew England atmosphere
in which he lived and wrote. Bom into a prosperous family, he yearned to write
poetry, but flet this desire conflicted with the expectations of his family and
friends who considered him an x idle dreamer. Be was a solitary poet, yielding
to no criticisms—even his own work shows little evidence of experimentation or
development. His later work follows the pattern of form, subjects, and technique
demonstrated in his earliest work.
Robinson had a genius for the dramatic exposition of an individual’s life
story, using understatement to build an ironic w&gnette, or story in worid. He
often wrote about the disparity between appearance and reality, particularly as
it related to failure of the individual measured by the standards of other
pepple. "Elassaonde" is a well-known poem illustrating this theme, and in
"Captain Craig", Robinson enlarged upon the subject to illustrate the many
aspects of life which measure a man1® success or failure.
Robinson won the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry in 1921, and although his
work is not as popular now as it once ms, he is still recogn ized as a highly
skilled poet of the dramatic monologue.
IV. VOCABULARY BOIES
downtown:
Referring to the busy commercial area of a population center. Ihis word
has broad usage, with variations of the phrase occurring in different areas
of the United States. Common variations are x uptown and to town. Inhabitants
of larger urban centers (Hew York, Chicago, San Fmncisco) may use the
